elements.text: [Part One]
Going through radio frequencies.

And the opening ceremony of the 2012 Olympics is underway.... This is a dark day for humanity.... The airship R101 has crashed in.... First steps onto the red planet.... The 1984 Olympic games will be opening tonight.... The outbreak of World War Five.... More updates after the weather. Earth Central lost contact with the outer colonies approximately three hours.... We wish you all a happy new millennium.... Stay with us for further updates... The Prince announced that St Gart’s Hospital will be.... We will know peace in our time.... The motorcade was travelling past the school book.... And we'll have more news after the weather.... Thousand six Commonwealth Games opened tonight... They're coming! They’re already here! ... Solar system is at war.... Was in Paris with Dodi.... New dawn for humanity... Peace in our time... Returning to our main item. It has been confirmed that the Soviet Union will not be taking part this years Olympic Games.
Knock on door.
Just a minute.
The games, due to be held in Los Angeles this summer.
Who is it?
[OC]: Mom, it’s me.
Oh, Mrs Van G, be a darling and let her in.
Footsteps, door opens.
Mom, I... Oh, hi, Mrs Van Gysengham. You're looking jazzy today. That colour really suits you.
Your daughter, Mrs Foster.
Door closes.
Suit yourself. Hi Mom.
Morning. Did you hear about the Russians?
Yeah. Oh, you know, sometimes the whole world just seems so small and petty.
A bit profound for before breakfast, darling.
Yeah, well. Anyway, I’m here to tell you that er, I won’t be coming today.
Surprise, surprise.
Oh, Peri, why not?
I guess I’m just not in a real cave mood right now. I wouldn’t want to cramp your style.
I’m sure we'll get on perfectly well without you.
Well, what are you going to do instead? You can’t mope around the hotel all day.
Oh, you know me, I'll think of something.
Are you all right?
No, no, it’s fine. Seriously. Lanzarote’s great, and the hotel’s great, and Mrs Van Gysengham here is just fantastic.
Ha.
But I just wanna, oh, I don’t know, explore.
Well, be careful.
I will. Anyway, where’s my dearest step-father?
Oh, you know Howard. He’ll be out on his boat searching for
+ PERI: the buried treasures of the deep.
Okay. Well, I’ll go and see him first. I, er, Mom? I'll er, I'll see you later.
Honey, are you sure you're all right?
I’m fine. I'll see you soon, yeah?
All right. Bye, darling.
Bye. Oh, and bye, bye, Mrs Van Gysengham.
Door opens and closes.
You let her get away with too much.
She has to find her own way.
Huh. She’s up to something.
I Know, but what can I do? She’s 18. I can hardly lock her in her room.
In my day, we made sure that children were
Yes, yes, yes, all right. But this is Peri we’re talking about. She knows what she’s doing. Now get your bag and let’s go. Although, knowing my daughter, there’s bound to be a man involved.
The Tardis materialises amongst whispering voices.
Come on, Peri.
Just a minute.
Honestly, I don’t know what takes you so long. It’s not as if you end up wearing much.
And there was me thinking you didn’t notice.
You’re not exactly dressed for the Ice Caves of Shabadabadon.
I can’t see any Ice Caves, Doctor. In fact, there’s a distinct lack of ice and a total absence of caves.
Yes, yes, yes. I thought we’d take a slight detour first. This is the Gogglebox. What do you think?
Cool.
Cool? The Gogglebox is one of the human race’s greatest achievements. Look at it! Embrace it.
Human? They all look a bit alien to me.
Oh, your lot are on one of their day trips away from Earth space. Solar flares or intergalactic wars or something. The usual.
Same old same old. So, where are we?
The Gogglebox! One of the human races
Greatest achievements. I’m embracing it already. But where are we?
Deep, deep down inside the Moon.
The Moon? The Moon moon? My Moon?
I don’t think it’s solely the property of Miss Perpugilliam Brown, but yes, Earth’s Moon.
Wow. Now that really is cool.
Well, I’m glad you’re finally impressed. Want to explore?
Do I have a choice?
You. Yes, you.
ALAN56: (Black country accent) Yes, sir. How can I help you?
My young friend and I have just arrived and we'd like to experience what the Gogglebox has to offer.
(sigh) Really. My name is Alan56 and I’m overjoyed to be showing you around the wondrous delights of the Gogglebox.
Overjoyed?
Yes, overjoyed. Now, if you'll follow me.
I thought you said all the humans were gone.
I suspect Alan56 here is a clone.
That’s right. The Gogglebox is staffed by 108 clones of the original Alan. And as he was happy to help, so are we all.
You don’t sound it.
ALANS5S6: I have been here for over two thousand years.
Oh. Never fancied trying anything else?
ALAN5E6: No.
He’s a bundle of laughs. So, er, what is this Gogglebox thing?
It’s an access system. It lets you view every recorded media event from the human race’s history.

Oh, come on, Alan. Put some welly into it. Peri, the Gogglebox lets you witness, no, experience anything. You can watch the first television performance of the Pussycat Dolls, the opening of the Jupiter colonies, every Police Academy film. You can see Battleship Potemkin, the creation of the Euro-combine, mankind’s momentous first meeting with the Mysterious Mymm! The human race has so much history, Peri. Oh, you could watch the execution of Great Britain’s last ruling monarch.
I could see what they’re up to at home!
What?
Alan, can I see the news from America in 1984?
What, that’s it? You could see anything, anything at all from Earth’s history, and that’s it? ALAN5B6: You could see that, madam, yes.
Fantastic!
Didn’t you hear me? Anything!
Yeah, and that’s what I wanna watch. What about you?
I need to find a book.
Barbara Cartland’s latest?
No, no. I think... Hmm, now that’s odd.
What, you thinking?
You’re quite the Oscar Wilde today, aren’t you.
I try.
No, it’s odd that for some reason I think I left it here, in the Gogglebox, but I can’t really remember.
And it’s important, this book?
It’s possibly the most important book in all of space and time! You don’t know the...
Damage it could cause. Yeah, yeah, okay, well, you go and find this so important book, and I'll check
out what’s happening at home.
Alan, torture her. Plug her in.
Hey.
ALANS5SE6: Very well. Madam, please step into the booth.
Oh. Right. Why thank you, kind sir. So, I just sit here?
Given this is an empty room with a chair in it, it’s probably a good idea, yes.
Smart a... (door closes)
And now, Alan, perhaps you help me look for my book. The fate of the entire universe could depend upon it.
I’m sure it could, sir.
Er, hello?
BOOTH/71: Hello, and welcome to Booth 71. Thank you for choosing me.
My pleasure.
BOOTH/71: Please select which era of human history you are interested in experiencing.
1984. Just the news, please.
[OC]: The actress Ethel Merman has died.
BOOTH/71: Would you like to hear more, or go to the next headline?
Next please.
[OC]: The space shuttle Challenger
Next!
[OC]: British coal miners have voted to go on strike.
Next.
[OC]: A new television series, Miami Vice, has
Next. No, look, wait. Computer, can I like, er, narrow down my choice?
BOOTH/71: Of course. Please specify.
I'd like the news, 1984, Baltimore, that’s in America.
BOOTH/71: I am aware of the geographical location. Here are the results of your search.
[OC]: A resident of Baltimore has been found brutally murdered in Saint Anne’s graveyard. BOOTH/71: Would you like to hear more, or go to the next headline?
Mmm, yeah, murder in the graveyard. Spooky.
[OC]: The local man, Anthony Chambers, a forty year old father of two, was working
Computer, stop! Mister Chambers? Oh. Computer, let me out!
BOOTH/71: Thank you for choosing booth 71. (receding) I hope the experience as been as much of a pleasure as
(running) Alan! Alan!
ALAN32: Yes, madam?
Yes, madam.
Oh, clones. Great. Where’s the Doctor?
ALAN32: The Doctor is with Alan56. Shall I take you to him?
Would you rather I did?
I don’t care which one of you. Look, just take me to him.
ALANS32: Hi, Alan56.
ALAN5SB6: Alan32, hello.
ALAN32: This madam would like to talk to the Doctor.
ALAN56: He said he was not to be disturbed under any circumstances.
Yeah, yeah, he always says that. Where is he?
He’s here. Alan, I’ve asked 14 of you, and no one seems to have any idea of where the book is.
Doctor, we’ve got to go back to the Tardis.
Oh, do we, indeed. May I ask why?
Someone’s been murdered back home.
Well, there’s not much we can do about it now. Now Alan, about this book.
You don’t understand. I knew him.
Peri, we’re thousands of years into your future. Everyone you know there is dead.
(crying) Doctor, take me home. I’ve got to see my Mom and... oh God, Kathy.
Kathy?
She’s my... was my best friend. Anthony’s daughter.
Anthony?
The man who’s been murdered! Come on, Doctor.
Very well. Although I don’t see what good it'll do. Thanks for your hospitality, Alan. Alans.
Thank you, Doctor. Well, keep up, Peri. We’ve a murder to investigate.
The Tardis dematerialises.
So he was a close friend, then?
He was my best friend’s dad.
You know we can’t stop it happening. We can’t change history.
I know! I just want to go to the funeral.
Yeah, very well. Right, let’s see what else... An, here we are.
[OC]: Shocked the entire community. A man is currently being questioned by local authorities in connection with Anthony Chamber’s death. The unnamed vagrant, who'd been sleeping in the graveyard

Denies all knowledge of the undertaker’s tragic demise. Meanwhile, friends and family of the murdered father of two are gathered together today for his funeral. I’m Natalie Hamilton, and you’re listening to Channel VNTR, the news you can trust.
Well, here we are. Baltimore, the 24'" of September 1984. How very grey. With an e.
It’s weird.
What is?
Just, one minute we’re there, thousands of years in the future, and the next, home.
Thank you, Reverend. I was a close friend of Anthony’s and I’m sure I speak for all
Oh. That’s, that’s my mom. There. Right there.
Mmn,, striking woman.
Yeah. Only she’d wear fuchsia to a funeral. No surprise it’s her making the speeches.
And what on Earth is that? Her, there. She’s got purple hair!
Oh, that’s Mrs Van Gysengham. We met her in Lanzarote. Wonder what she’s doing here? I’d best, well, I'd better go.
Well, I won't say hello. Probably best if you catch up without me.
Yeah. What am I gonna say? She'll want to know where I’ve been.
Well, tell her.
Yeah, I don’t think that'll work. Wonder where Howard is?
Howard?
My step-father. You met him before Turlough rescued me.
Peri, do you know how many people I’ve met? Really, I can’t be expected to remember all
Not here, Doctor. Not now.
No. No, no. Well, how about I try and find out more about this vagrant character? We can meet up later.
Yeah. Doctor?
Mmm hmm?
Don’t... well, you know, don’t turn this into something.
Hmm?
I mean, this is my home, yeah? My family, my friends. Don’t turn it into some big adventure.
I do wish you'd have a little bit more faith in me.
Okay, okay. Oh, and Doctor?
Oh, what now?
Don’t go too far. I still want to see the Ice Caves of Shabadabadoodah.
You will. Take care.
Here goes.
That’s it. You two okay?
I can’t... Oh, I don’t know.
You'll be fine. Trust me.
Gonna have to face it. He’s gone.
Nate, you don’t have to... oh, forget it.
It’s okay, kids. You’re both gonna find it difficult, but I’m here for you. Now, did you want to stay here for a while or come back to mine for the wake?
Got plenty of beer in?
I don’t understand you. Daddy’s dead. Can you get that? Oh.
Hi.
Peri?
Hi, Nate. Kathy. Mom.
So, you decided to show your face, then.
Mom, I’ve...
Save it, Peri. Today for once the world does not revolve around you.
I’m sorry.

Aren’t we all. Come on, you two. We'll head back. Now, it’s going to be difficult. You’re going to have every Tom, Dick and Jane telling you how sorry they are and how much they're going to miss Anthony,
and you're going to be feeling awful, (receding) but in a few hours it'll be over and you can just be alone.

Mom? Mister Chambers, it’s Peri. Peri Brown? I’m sorry. Sorry I wasn’t here for you and everything, and I don’t know what to say ‘cos I am talking to a box. Sorry. I hope it wasn’t (bursts into tears).
Oh, don’t turn it into some big adventure. Honestly, you offer to help and that’s all the thanks you get. Now, how am I going to.... An ha. Purple hair. Mrs Van Gysengham?
Hello?
Coo-ee. It’s me, Mrs Van Gysengham. Can I have a word?
Er, yes? Er, what is it?
Ah now, terrible business, all this.
Yes. I’m sorry, but have we er, when did we meet?

It’s me. We met in Lanzarote. Don’t you remember that night in the bar? Oh, I'll never forget the look on Howard’s face as you told that story, mmm? You know, the one where you, and then they both, and nobody (laughs) didn’t realise. Oh dear, it was such a funny story.
Oh. Oh yes. Of course. Er, how are you?
Doctor.
Oh, Doctor.
Yes.
Of course. How are you?
Ah well, as well as can be expected after what’s happened.
I know. A terrible business. Poor Mister Chambers.
Terrible is precisely the word. Still, at least they've got the monster who did it.
Well, there’s the rub. He’s denying it and well, I’m not one for talk, but Daniel Woods is rather old.
Daniel Woods?
The vagrant.
Hmm?
He lived in a tent, you know. A tent! Who lives in a tent these days? I gather it was a blue one. Probably a Democrat. Never understood them.
Ah, no, really, no, no. Well, I wonder
You want to know something else? I don’t think he did it.
Oh? What makes you think that?
I'll tell you on the way. You are going to the wake, yeah?
Oh, yes.
Hop in and I'll give you a lift.
Oh, thank you. So you don’t think it was him?
No. No, the clues just don’t add up. (car doors slam) Belt up.
What? Oh, yes. What clues?
Car drives off.
Mister Chambers was quite a healthy man, all things considered.
All things considered?
All that time surrounded by the dead. (tyres squealing) Never good for anyone’s... get out of the way! For anyone’s spirit.
Indeed. Perhaps you’d just like to slow down?
Where is it you’re from, Doctor?
Oh, you know. Watch out for the...
Heavy braking.
English? I lived in England for a while, in London.
That, that traffic.
I know. How anyone gets around that city alive I don’t know. My first husband owned a pub there. I didn’t really approve. The White Rabbit, on the Embankment.
Er, yes, yes, I know it. Now, Mrs Van Gysengham...
Before he died, of course. (tyres squeal) My right of way! And that must have been eight six eight er seven years ago.
(sotto) A car accident or euthanasia? (normal) Well, I’m sorry to hear that. Now...
After he died...
Anthony Chambers.

I moved to Miami Beach. Lovely place, but full of old people. Then husband number two’s heart went bang. (tyres squeal) Watch it! So I moved here. It’s nice. I’ve been able to support poor Janine over the last couple of months. She’s had such a hard time of it, you know. Oh, that daughter of hers, just
Oh yes, I know. Shocking behaviour. So, Anthony Chambers was healthy and
Oh yes, fit as a fiddle. But — and this is the clincher - Daniel Woods, he’s seventy if he’s a day, there’s no way on this Earth he could have done that to Mister Chambers.
Done what?
Snapped his neck. He wouldn’t have had the strength. Mark my words, Doctor, that vagrant didn’t kill him.
And where (tyres squeal, gasps) where is he now?
Daniel Woods? They're holding him at Fells Point police station. Mrs Doyle’s son works there. He’s a funny one too. Never had a girl friend.
Ah now, Mrs Van Gysengham, there’s something I’ve got to tell you.
Yes dear, what is it?
Well, you’ve probably worked it out already.
What’s that, my love?
I’m not just here to mourn Mister Chambers’ tragic demise. I’m here to investigate it.
British intelligence? I thought so. Not much gets past me.
(sotto) The way you drive I’m not (normal) Yes, that’s it, yes. I need you to drive me to the police station.
Fells Point?
Face the road!!! Sorry. Yes, yes, that’s the one.
I knew there was something about you. Is that why you’re wearing that, that er
Oh, I’m meant to be undercover, as an American.
How exciting. So you’re a secret agent like James Bond.
Indeed I am. And you’ve given me exactly the information I needed.
I'll put my foot down, then.
No.
To the police station, Doctor!
No, no, there’s really.... Oh, forget it.

You wouldn’t believe where I’ve been, Mister Chambers. Remember that time you took me and Kathy out on the porch and showed us the Moon? Remember you had that telescope, before Nate broke it. So, you showed us the Moon and you said how one day we’d be living up there. I’ve been there, Mister Chambers. I’ve seen so much that it’s just... I wish you could have seen it. I’ve been to the past and the future, and other planets, and so much. It’s even bigger than you could have imagined.

[OC]: I’m so sorry. I really am. I should have come back before, seen you one last time. I guess I should go home, see the others, and Mom. Wish me luck. I don’t think I’ve ever been so scared. Goodbye, Mister Chambers.
There is nothing to fear.
You sure you don’t want me to wait, hun?
Oh, no, no, no, no. Thank you. You’ve been a great help.
I'll see you at the wake, then. Bye, bye.
Bye, bye.
Car roars away.
Carry on driving like that and it'll be your own wake. Oh. 1984. It’s never as good as the book. Oh well, here goes.
Door opens and closes.
Hello.
Good afternoon. Can I help you?
Yes, I hope you can. I’d like to see Mister Daniel Woods, the man you’ve charged with Anthony Chambers’ murder.
Sorry, I’m afraid that won’t be possible.
Why not?
Well, because he’s under arrest, for murder.
And?
And that means we can’t just let anyone in.
I’m not just anyone. I’m the Doctor, and I’m here on behalf of UNIT. I presume you’ve heard of them. The United
No.

Oh. Well, this case has ramifications not just for America but for the entire planet. I am here at the personal request of the Secretary General, so unless you want to be responsible for an international incident, it would probably be a good idea if you let me see him.
(sighs) Do you have any identification?

Hmm? Identifi... Oh. Oh, very well. Now, let’s see. Well, I’ve got... oh, actually, would you mind holding this? No. No, that’s no good. Oh, thought I’d lost that. What on Earth’s an Oyster card? Never mind. Now, oh, that’d be handy if I were on Oakes Minor, but... ah
[OC]: An apple. You know what they say. Wait, I’ve got a library card in here somewhere. Cuddly toy.
Facial analysis confirms it is the Doctor.
[OC]: Understood.
[OC]: Tickets to the opening night of the Rocky Horror Picture Show.
A pair of socks?
That will be fine, sir. You may see the prisoner.
I may? Oh, well, that’s very good of you. Lead on.
This way, sir.
Well, I’m sure you understand, we just want to get... Are you all right?
Sir?
Your ear. You seem to have
My ear is fine. Here we are.
Door creaks open.
Hello.
Who are you?
I’m here to help. Thank you. You can return to your duties.
Sir.
Door closes and is locked.
Hello.
So, have you come to kill me?
Oh God. It hasn’t changed. It’s all the same.
Bobby, come inside, you’re getting soaked.
Here goes.
Doorbell. Door opens, babble of voices.
Lost your key?
Mom, I’m sorry.
Yes, you said.
Can I come in?
Of course you can. Just remember why everyone’s here.
Door closes.
I can’t believe he’s dead. Mister Chambers.
I Know. It’s wrong.
How are Kathy and Nate taking it?
How do you think?
Please don't.
What do you expect... Look, go and get something to eat, or something, and we'll talk later. I’ve got a full house.
Okay. Mom, where’s Howard?
Well, I did accuse him of being responsible for my daughter’s death. That kind of thing tends to have a negative effect on one’s marriage.
Dead? He thought I was dead?
Just go and... not now, Peri.
Hey, you’ve nothing to be scared of. I’m not here to kill you.
Are you... I Know who you are.
I somehow doubt that.
You're one of the monsters!
No.
Then, then you’re being controlled by them.
No.
Come here. Let me see.
Hmm? Ow! Gentle.
There’s nothing there.
And why should I have anything in my ear?
That’s how they do it. That’s how they control them.
Control who?
Everyone. I saw it. I saw it kill the undertaker.
You saw who killed Anthony Chambers?
Yes, it was... I saw it!
Shh, shh, shh.
I saw it. I saw it.
Yes?
Eight six eight seven.
What? What do you mean? (door opens) Officer. Oh, er, sorry, didn’t catch your name.
Lieutenant Doyle, sir. I’ve brought you some coffee.
Well, that’s very good of you, but I didn’t ask for any.
I brought you some anyway.
No, not today, thank you.
You should drink the coffee.
Oh. Oh, I should, should I? Thank you. Ouch. Ah. It’s hot.
Drink the coffee.
No.
Drink it.
Why don’t you drink it? Here you go, Lieutenant Doyle.
That is... that is not allowed.
Isn’t it? And why would that be, eh? (sniffs) Ah yes, you can really smell that cyanide. And usually I take mine with just a dash of milk.
Knock on door.
Who is it?
[OC]: The geek.
Kathy, come in.
Door opens and closes.
Here, I brought you some coffee.
Thanks, but I’m okay.
Try and drink some. It’s all been a bit, well, a bit of a shock. Oh, it’s a while since I’ve been in here. Miss Brown’s boudoir.
Tell me about it. Mom hasn’t changed a thing.
Pillow fight?
God, feels like so long ago.
Things change.
Yeah. Kathy, I’m so sorry about your Dad.
Please don't.
What?
That’s all I’ve had all day. Oh, Katherine, I’m so sorry to hear about, embarrassed mumble, trail off, walk away.
Mom said.... Did you really think I’d died?
Is that what she told you? No. Howard told her you were going off travelling. I mean, yeah, she was furious because he’d left you on a boat, but we all knew that wouldn’t stop you.
It nearly did. I nearly drowned. And they split up over that?
I guess there were other issues. Let’s face it, he never really gave your Mom the respect she deserved. I think that was the final straw.
Yeah, right. Poor Howard.
So, where have you been?
Oh, you know, all over. And then some.
You could have sent a postcard. It’s been four months.
Four months? It’s been ye... It feels like longer. So, did you miss me?
Nah, not really. Course I did! Who else got me into as much trouble as you? My grades have improved though.
What about the others? Do you still see Candy?
Not much. And no, she still hasn’t forgiven you for the Prom.
(laughs) No. And what about Eunice?
Oh yah, you missed that. She got married!
No way!
Yah, to Jason.
No! You're lying. You are so telling me lies, Kathy Chambers.
No, seriously.
And what about Nate?
Ah, don’t worry about him. He’s not exactly been pining after you.
Oh, I didn’t expect him to.
Urgh, just thinking about you two together. (shudders)
Hey, if it had worked out, you could have been the bridesmaid.
Oh, story of my life. Peri.
Yeah?
Eight six eight seven.
What?
What? What did I say? Oh, that'll be me losing it.
Door opens, murmur of voices.
Hi. Hope I’m not interrupting anything.
Ah, just catching up, aren’t we?
Yeah. Mom, I
Kathy, people are starting to leave.
Suppose I have to do the whole ‘thanks for coming yes I'll call you if I need anything’ shtick.
I’m sorry, hun, but your brother’s passed out on the sofa.
You coming, Peri?
I er
Do you mind if she doesn’t? Actually, I’d like to talk.
Oh, okay. Glad you’re back.
Yeah. Good luck.
Door closes.
Okay?
Yeah. What about you? You glad I’m back?
He’s trying to poison you? I told you. I told you they’re all involved.
So it would seem. I’ve already been identified as a threat. That’s got to be a record for me.
Drink the coffee, Time Lord.
At gunpoint? That’s a sweetener, certainly. Now, officer, this coffee, oh it is hot, isn’t it?
Yes, so drink
Drink it. I know. Or, I could suddenly, say, throw it in your face? Now that would scald you, possibly distract you long enough for Mister Woods and I to escape.
That is logical..
That’s what I thought. And logically, would you want me to do that? Throw the coffee in your face?
That would impair my sight. If my sight was impaired then I could not sufficiently carry out my function.
Therefore the logical thing to do would be to let us escape without me throwing it at you.
That is... logical.
Very good. Come along, Mister Woods.
He’s being controlled.
Indeed he is, but not terribly well. Either the Lieutenant has a strong will, or the control is rather weak.
Yeah, but who by? Who's controlling him?
Oh, I’ve got a good idea.
Who's doing this?
The real question is, how many others are affected? And that would appear to be the answer. No, don’t come any closer. I’ve got coffee, and I’m not afraid to use it.
Who are you?
The Doctor. They’re waiting for new orders, so let’s get out of here.
And go where?
Where else, Mister Woods. The graveyard, of course. The scene of the crime. I want to know what happened
What do you mean?
I said, I want to know what happened. Where have you been?
Travelling.
Oh, come on, you owe me more than that.
You wouldn't believe me.
Try me. Your travelling destroyed my marriage.
Don’t say that.

You’re not a child. You can face the truth. You come to my hotel room and tell me that you'll find something to do. I come back from the caves and Howard tells me you’re going travelling with some English guys. He says he’s left you on a boat and that you’re fine. Then we go to fetch you and you’re gone! We thought you’d drowned! Of course, he was more worried about some artefact you’d stolen.
I didn’t mean to. I didn’t want to. It was an accident.
Where did you go for four months? Where did you go? When were you thinking of coming back, huh? Next month? Next year? 1986, 87? When?
I... fine. There was this man.
Oh well, there’s a surprise.
Like mother, like daughter.
Don't even try it. Your father died, I moved on.
Pretty quickly, though.
You know what? I’m not going to apologise anymore. You think what you like.
Oh, I do.
You're a selfish little... You don’t even care, do you.

I need you to take me back to the beginning. I need you to help me ensure that the human race is all one, all Cyberman.
Okay, you two stay back. I’m going in.
I think you’re forgetting who you're talking to.
Done this kind of thing before, have you, Mom?
You're not too old for a
No, Mom, I am too old. I’m not your little girl any more.
Oh stop it, you two.
Come on, follow me. The tape’s stopped.
Nate? (screams)
There will be no emotion, no fear. You will pilot the pod (gurgle) You will pilot us to the beginning of life on Earth.
Must we? I’ve been there a few times now. I wouldn’t want to bump into myself.
Set the coordinates for prehistoric Earth.
No, I can’t. Really, I can’t.
Then I will order the Cyberman to kill the remaining humans.
You can be very persuasive, can’t you. Ever considered a job in marketing? Course laid in, Captain.
Activate. You will now take the conversion device.
This it? Looks like an egg?
The device splits into... into... into two pieces.
Oh, so it does. And er, what, one on each side of the head, like this?
That begins the conversion process. The human flesh is then turned into Cyber- technology.
(Tommy Cooper) Just like that, ho, ho. It’s very advanced, flesh into metal. This what you used on Anthony Chambers?
Correct. It is Time Lord technology. I adapted it. It is your future, Doctor.
I'd rather not know about that, thanks.
You will convert the first humans. They will then have the knowledge and ability to develop further Cyber-technology. You will leave the device with them and they will convert all life on the planet.
So, no homo sapiens.
From their birth, the human race will be Cybermen.
Quite a plan. One question, though.
One (gurgle) Doctor?
Why me? Oh, I realise you needed me to pilot the ship, but why don’t you convert them?
You are responsible for the final destruction of my race. It is suitable that you create the new Cyber-race.
Revenge? Irony? No, no, no. That’s a bit too emotional for you. You really are dying, aren’t you.
That is correct. I can no longer leave this vessel. I have tried to... tried to link with it.
And now you're trapped. But you left it to kill Anthony.
That was necessary. That was the final... the final act.
You mean it took it all out of you. Now there’s irony. By killing that innocent man, you ‘ve sentenced yourself to death.
That is unimportant. (gurgle) You will change history and then pilot us to our new future. If you do not, I shall give the order for your companions to be eliminated.
But if I change the past, they'll never be born at all.
Then you shall experience no grief. If you do not change the past and we return to the current timeline, I will ensure that their deaths are... emotional. We have arrived.
Prehistoric Earth?
That is correct. You will now leave the pod.
And destroy the future.
Nate. Nate.
It’s... Kathy, he’s still alive.
That thing, it’s just standing there.
Waiting for orders, I bet. Nate, lie still.
Lemme, lemme look.
My legs.
No, don’t talk. Stay calm. Just breathe.
We need to get him out of here. Carry him to the bathroom.
No, no, he can’t be moved. Lemme have a... oh God. Nate, I’m just going to talk to Janine, okay? You just stay there. That’s it.
What?
His back, it’s broken.
Oh no. Oh my God. I’m so sorry.
No. Well, we can er... broken?
Where’s your Doctor now, Peri?
What are we gonna do, Mom?
I'll think of something. Just let’s all stay calm. Right, okay, Peri, you talk to Nate. Keep him talking. Don’t let him go to sleep. Kathy, look at me. Kathy!
I’m sorry.
Don't be silly. Right, you’re going to the bathroom, yeah? Just you, all right?
Right.
You’re gonna lock yourself in. Peri? Peri.
What?
This Tardis thing, what does it look like?
A blue box. British police box.
Okay. And have you got a key?
Here. It’s over by the trees at the edge of the graveyard.

Right. Kathy, I want you in the bathroom. Lock yourself in. I’m going to try to get rid of the Cyberman, okay? I'll be sending Peri to join you shortly, but if anything happens before then, you go back to this Tardis and you call the Doctor’s alien friends or something. You get them here to help us, okay?
I can’t just leave.
We can’t move him, and there’s no point in us all being in danger. Now go!
Okay.
Right. Now Peri, why aren’t you talking to Nate? I told you to talk to him. I’m gonna try and well, get rid of the Cyberman.
Okay. Nate? Can you hear me? It’s Peri. Nathaniel, listen to me. It’s me, Perpugilliam, remember? Your stupid name, my stupid name. Remember we were going to get them changed?
Anthony.
CYBER-ANTHONY: Anthony Chambers no longer exists. I am a Cyberman now.
If I go out there, I destroy everything.
That is incorrect. You will create order.
Why can’t you understand? The human race, the universe, isn’t meant to be logical. Chaos, emotion, that’s what it’s all about. That's life.
You are incorrect. I have studied Time, and there are patterns.
Patterns?
Patterns throughout Time. The order is hidden, but it does exist. Every aspect of life is part of something greater.
Oh great, a Cyberman who want to get philosophical. And what happens to me, when we go back to your glorious Cyber-future?
I have studied you, Doctor. Your life does not concern you.
You’ve an answer for everything, haven't you.
You will now leave the pod. Take the conversion device.
It seems I have no choice.
That is correct. Soon we shall be home.
So, you see, there’s nothing to worry about, because the Doctor can do anything. I know it looks like he’s gone (continues under)
Anthony. Anthony Chambers, can you hear me?
CYBER-ANTHONY: There is nothing to fear.
Who said anything about being scared? This is me you're talking to. Janine Foster. CYBER-ANTHONY: You will be like us.

Listen to me. That's it, look at me. I need you to try and remember who you are, okay? Remember me. Remember your kids. Remember Nate and Kathy, and do you remember Jessica, your wife? CYBER-ANTHONY: Jessica.
That’s right. She died, remember?
CYBER-ANTHONY: It is irrelevant.

No, it’s not. Don’t tell me it’s irrelevant. Remember how it was? You, Jess, me and Paul. You remember Paul, my husband? Paul. You and him always watching your movies. Remember Thursday nights? Paul and Anthony’s movie night. Do you remember movie night?
CYBER-ANTHONY: Bond.

That’s it. The name’s Bond. James Bond. Remember how you both used to get so drunk and you’d come back and the kids would be in bed, and Jess would make you sleep on the sofa and CYBER-ANTHONY: Sleep.
What's that, hun? You wanna sleep? Well, why don’t you? Why don’t you just go to sleep there. This is your home. You can sleep here..
CYBER-ANTHONY: Sleep.
That’s it. Go to sleep. Okay, Peri? I want you to get ready to join Kathy.
Mom? I wish Dad was still here.
I know. I wish Dad was here too. I do miss him, you know. I always have.
I’m sorry. Sorry I’ve been so bad about it all. So bad to you.
It’s okay. Now go lock yourself in the bathroom.
Nate? You’re gonna be okay.
That’s it. Just quietly leave.
CYBER-ANTHONY: No.
No, it’s okay, Anthony. You stay there.
CYBER-ANTHONY: The young female must not leave.
Mom?
Anthony, stand still. Stay where you are. Peri, just go.
CYBER-ANTHONY: No!
Get off me! Let me go!
Let her go!
CYBER-ANTHONY: She will be terminated.
Peri screams.
Doctor.
It’s done.
How many? How many did you convert?
Eight. And they’re already converting the others.
You left the device (gurgle) with them?
Yes. Yes. Now, let’s go. Let’s see your glorious future.
Use the panel to your right. Set the temporal coordinates.
1984. A world where everyone conforms. No emotion, no chaos. The Orwellian nightmare come true. That’s it, we’re on our way.
Excellent. The patterns will be complete.
Yes.
You have created a new history, Doctor. You should feel pride.
Pride? How can I feel pride when I know that once I could have stopped your race ever being created? I could have stopped all this ever happening. We've arrived.
The future, Doctor.
Well, why don’t you go out there and embrace it? You'll have enough energy for that. And I’m sure their perfect Cyber-technology can fix you up, make you better.
Stomping recedes.
Here we are, 1984.
It is (gurgle) perfect. The logic, the pattern, is complete.
You know, I'd love to stay and find out more about this patt... ow!
You will stay, Doctor.
My arm!
You will stay, Doctor. Look at the future.
You really should get yourself looked at. You’re not sounding too healthy.
It is... itis... Doctor.
Oh, that’s better. What is it, Cyberleader? What have you seen? Surely not imperfection?
These Cybermen, they are... they are... inferior.
You all are. Welcome home, Cyberleader. Enjoy your future, what's left of it. Goodbye and good riddance!
What are you? Why are you (gurgle) inferior?
A sing-song early Mondasian Cyberman.
You are defective.
Affirmative. I need repairs. You are inferior.
Negative. We are the Cybermen.
Is this... is this... is this 1984?
Affirmative.
Is this... is this Earth?
It is Mondas. Commander Zheng, you will take this unit for reprocessing.
Affirmative.
Negative.
Peri!
CYBER-ANTHONY: Termination aborted.
Mom?
CYBER-ANTHONY: Awaiting further instructions.
Oh God, Peri, I thought I’d lost you.
Lose Peri in that get-up?
Doctor! You're alive!
Of course I am. Now what’s happening with the Cyberman?
He’s waiting for further orders.
He'll be waiting for a while, then. The Cyber-Leader’s no longer here. Look out the window and you'll see a group of confused policemen wondering what they’re doing standing about a graveyard.
Where’s the, the Cyber-Leader?
I took him home.
Home?

He though I'd changed Earth’s history and brought him back to a new timeline, one where none of you would have existed. Just a planet full of Cybermen. I just adjusted the spatial coordinates slightly and took him back to Mondas.
But that’s... not destroyed until 1986!
Exactly. Right time, wrong place. Oh, and he gave me this.
What is it?
Is it all over?
Yeah.
Kathy! This, Janine, is an egg.
Hmm. Your expert opinion?
It’s from my future. Converts humans into machines. The Cyber-Leader wanted me to use it to convert the first humans. Peri, hold onto it for me. Oh, Nathanial. I’m so sorry.
Doctor.
You're alive! He’s alive!
His back, Doctor. Is there anything you can do?
I’m sorry, Peri. I can’t. We'll get him to a hospital, though.
Then it’s really all over?
Yes, Janine. It’s all over.
This egg conversion thing, can I keep it? I can put it in the basement, you know, along with Mom’s new space pod. It'll be safe down there, away from prying eyes.
Oh, stand back.
That’s it, Mrs Simpson. Keep breathing. In, out. You’re doing great.
Ah, new life. It’s a wonderful thing.
Yeah. Mom? Kathy?
There’s not much they can do. He’s paralysed.
Oh God. I’m so sorry.
But he’s alive, Kathy.
And where there’s life.
Oh, Janine, I need to get out of here.
Of course. Come on. Peri? Doctor?
Give us a few minutes. We'll see you back at the house.
Okay, we'll see you then.
You didn’t want the long goodbye, then.
No.
Where first? Back to the Gogglebox, or... Peri? Peri, what is it?
(crying) I’m not... I’m not coming with you. I’m staying here, Doctor.
What?
I can’t. I can’t leave them again.
But, but, but the Ice Caves of Sha...
I’m sorry but no. I’ve made up my mind.
You'll... you'll miss me.
And you'll miss me too.
Peri, are you absolutely sure?
Sorry, Doctor, but look me up, yeah? Come back and see me. Right now you... you brought me home.
Leaves, crying.
Peri.
The Tardis materialises, door opens and closes.
ALAN5B6: Doctor, welcome back.
Ah, hello, Alan. How are you?
ALANS56: Fine. Your companion not with you?
Er no. No, no, she’s... home.
ALAN56: I suppose you want us to help you find that book.
It doesn’t seem important now.
ALAN56: No?

I'll tell you what, though. Show me to one of the booths. I want to see how she gets on. Oh, she'll be brilliant, but that’s only to be expected. After all, she’s learnt from the best. ALAN56: Of course. Follow me.
You okay, honey?
Yeah. I just... I can’t believe I’m back. For good.
I’m so happy. Really, it’s so good to have you here.
Yeah, it’s good. It’s good to be home.
ALAN56: Doctor?
No! Peri!
ALAN56: Doctor? Doctor!
Tardis door opens and closes, Tardis dematerialises.
Door opens.
Hello? Anyone home?
Mrs Van Gysengham?
That’s right, dear.
Oh, I’m just upstairs.
Door closes.
You been abandoned again?
No, no. Peri’s enrolling at Uni and Kathy’s visiting Nate.
Ah ha. A perfect opportunity to snoop.
No, no. You know what girls are like. There’s a whole load of dirty laundry up here. Oh.
What is it?
I found something. It was the Doctor’s.
The British guy?
Yeah, yeah. It’s alien.
Oh, is it.
Turns flesh into metal.
Oh, does it?
Yeah. I'd left it in the basement, though. What do you think?
It’s very pretty. It’s like half an egg.
Yeah. I wonder where the other bit is? Oh, what’s CYBER-DEVICE: Unauthorised use of conversion device. Self-destruct programme activated.
Oh, that doesn’t sound
KaBOOM!

There’s been a massive explosion in the Fells Point area. Police are treating it as suspicious. The dead women have been named as Janine Foster and Dominique Van Gysengham. Friends and neighbours have been paying their respects.

(crying) Mom? I don’t know what to say to you. You’re probably up there now, laughing at me. My Perpugilliam with nothing to say. I still don’t believe it. One minute you’re there and then... oh God. Mom.
(sotto) Peri.
Doctor?
It’s me. I am so sorry.
She’s gone. Just gone.
There’s nothing I can say. No words.
Kathy’s just disappeared, and Nate, they said he’d been transferred, and I don’t understand what’s happened. I don’t understand.
Neither do I, Peri. The universe is chaotic, a mystery.
It’s almost like the Cyberman had the right idea. They don’t... don’t have to go through this.
Shh. Don’t think like that. You mustn’t.
I know.
There, there. There, there.
I can’t stay here. There’s nothing for me.
I know. I know. Come on. Come on, come on.
The Tardis dematerialises.
Over closing theme.

Travelling with the Doctor’s the strangest, maddest experience. One minute your life is small, nine to five, next you’re seeing, well, everything, and it’s terrifying, but brilliant. Then one day, like all things, it ends. You leave him, you go home, and everything’s small again. But you get used to it. And the last thing you ever, ever expect, is for him to come back.

DOYLE: Suspects are trapped inside.
DOYLE: [OC]: The Doctor is trapped.

DOYLE: There is nothing to fear.

KATHY: They’re just standing there, watching.

KATHY: Why aren’t they coming after us?
JANINE: I said, get away from the window. For once just listen to me.
PERI: Mom, it’s okay. There’s no need to get so

DOCTOR: Hmm?
JANINE: Look at me.
DOCTOR: What is it?
JANINE: What the hell have you done to my daughter? What is going on? They’re just children, and because of you they're here.
PERI: Hey, that’s not fair. I brought you here.
JANINE: And you're just a kid. I don’t know what’s happened here, but you’re just a
WOODS: I’m sorry, but can I just say that I saw Anthony being murdered. I saw what happened. We need to stop it.
JANINE: And just who the hell are you? You're the one they say killed him.
WOODS: I’m sorry, I... Mrs Foster, yes?
JANINE: Yes.
WOODS: Okay, Mrs Foster. If we don’t do something, if we don’t try and stop all this, then what happened to Anthony, what’s happened to all of them out there, that’s going to happen to all of us. Don’t you see? We have to try and stop it.
JANINE: They’re just children.
NATE: We're not. He’s right.
JANINE: I just, I just wanna make sure you’re safe, all three of you.
DOCTOR: Then we need to stop this happening. Okay, Peri. What do you think?
PERI: Well, there’s a Cyberman and it brainwashed Anthony.
WOODS: And the police.
PERI: And the police.
DOCTOR: So why Anthony Chambers?
PERI: Something to do with his job. He said the dead will walk.
DOCTOR: Which we’ve already seen.
KATHY: The coffin.
DOCTOR: Exactly. It’s the coffins, it has to be. But this isn’t like them. They usually convert the living.
PERI: I remember.
DOCTOR: And now they’re using the dead. Tell me, Mrs Foster. How long had Anthony been working here?
JANINE: Er, about three months.
NATE: And it was just after starting here that Dad changed. He became quiet, distant.
DOCTOR: So let’s assume that after Anthony moved here, somehow a Cyberman managed to take control of his mind. It made him install some kind of conversion unit into the coffins. Any idea how many people have been buried here in the last three months?
KATHY: At least twenty.
DOCTOR: So that’s twenty more out there like your father, waiting underground. Waiting to be activated.
WOODS: Maureen.
DOCTOR: Your wife? I’m sorry, Daniel.
WOODS: She could be alive?
DOCTOR: No, no. They’re not alive. Look at Anthony. He didn’t recognise his own children. They’re not alive.
JANINE: Peri. It recognised Peri.

PERI: But wait! Doctor, Doctor, we met them in 1985! That’s next year.
KATHY: What?
DOCTOR: Next year? That means they’re from the future. Oh, brilliant, just brilliant. So now we’re dealing with time-travelling Cybermen. Oh, this gets better.
WOODS: So what do we do?
DOCTOR: Well, we can wait here, wait to die.
PERI: And become like them.
JANINE: Or we do something about it.
DOCTOR: Exactly. We need to look around here. The policeman I met had something in his ear, some kind of controlling device.
WOODS: They all do.
DOCTOR: Which means somewhere there’s a unit controlling them, and I’d hazard a guess that it’s in here somewhere.
PERI: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Yes?
PERI: Doesn’t that mean... doesn’t that mean there’s likely to be a Cyberman in this building, controlling them?
DOCTOR: I’m afraid so, yes. That’s why they don’t want us leaving.
JANINE: There’s a back door. Which they'll be watching too.
DOCTOR: Nathaniel, Kathy, you know this place better than any of us.
KATHY: Well, this is Dad’s office, and through there is... is where he keeps the bodies.
NATE: And then upstairs is where we live. Lived.
PERI: You live here? In the graveyard?
KATHY: Dad said it'd be easy for work.
DOCTOR: Whereas actually it made it easier for the Cybermen. Right. Peri, you take the others upstairs, 1’ll go through the back and see what’s there.
PERI: I’m coming with you.
JANINE: You’re not.
PERI: I am.
JANINE: Then I’m coming with you.
DOCTOR: All right, all right, fine. You three go upstairs, have a look round but make yourselves safe. I need you to find a room which can be locked from the inside.
WOODS: Understood. Come on you two.
KATHY: Peri, they said he killed my
PERI: It’s all right. You'll be fine.
NATE: Come on, Kathy. Let’s go. Mister Woods?
PERI: Okay. Mom? Doctor? Let’s go look at that morgue.
DOYLE: Halt. Who’s there?
DOYLE: CYBER-ANTHONY: I... I remember I was Anthony Chambers. Now who am I?
DOYLE: You’re a Cyberman. You’re what we all will be.
DOYLE: CYBER-ANTHONY: I... I... feel fear.
DOYLE: That'll pass. The Leader says that you will soon stop feeling.
DOYLE: CYBER-ANTHONY: That... that will be excellent.
DOYLE: I can, I can hear his voice. He’s telling me you should go into the building. You should find your old family, make them like you.
DOYLE: CYBER-ANTHONY: They will all be like us. How will I... I enter?
DOYLE: He’s telling me there’s a window on the first floor. Climb up and enter through that. CYBER-ANTHONY: Understood. (stomps away)
DOYLE: Soon we will all be like you.
NATE: Kathy, what if it’s up there?
KATHY: Think about it logically. It was making Dad do something to the coffins. It'll be downstairs.
NATE: Peri and Janine are there. They're going to face it?
KATHY: I think... I don’t think Peri’s the same as she used to be, Nate. I think she’s used to this.
WOODS: I think they both are. It’s like... it’s like a game for them.
NATE: A game?
WOODS: This is what they do.
NATE: Good for them. I’ll stick to football. Less deadly.
KATHY: The way you play?
NATE: Yeah, all right. Here we are, then
KATHY: Home.
PERI: Nice.
DOCTOR: Indeed.
JANINE: What are we looking for?
PERI: Alien technology.
JANINE: Alien technology, she says, like that’s an everyday thing. Peri?
PERI: What?
JANINE: You said... you said you’d been to 1985?
PERI: That’s nothing. I’ve been everywhere.
DOCTOR: You haven't been to the Ice Caves of Shabadabadon.
PERI: That’s the next stop, though.
JANINE: You travel in time?
PERI: And space.
JANINE: Oh. You did say you’d been travelling.
PERI: And I was being a good little girl. It wasn’t a lie.
JANINE: And this whole time-travel life thing would explain how you know about these Cybermen?
PERI: Do you believe me?
JANINE: How. Just tell me how.
DOCTOR: We don't really have time.
PERI: Yeah, we do. Mom, when I left you in the hotel, I was all set to go to Morocco with these two guys. I went to see Howard, who abandoned me on the boat, so I decided to swim for it. I got a cramp and nearly drowned, but this guy Turlough rescued me. He took me to the Tardis and when I woke up
JANINE: Whoa, back up a bit. Tardis?
PERI: Time And Relative Dimension In Space.
JANINE: Yeah, and that means?
PERI: A time machine. A ship that can go anywhere. Anyway, by the time I woke up, we were on our way to this planet called Sarn, and after that I decided to stay with the Doctor.
DOCTOR: I’ve been trying to get rid of her ever since.
PERI: Ha, ha. So that’s what happened. That’s why I haven’t been home. That's why I couldn’t send a postcard. That’s why I haven’t been here. Because it’s a time machine, I always figured I could get back before you knew I’d been away.
JANINE: Is this the truth?
PERI: What?
JANINE: Are you telling me the truth?.
PERI: Yes. I promise.
JANINE: Okay. Fair enough.

TEGAN: Travelling with the Doctor’s the strangest, maddest experience. One minute your life is small, nine to five, next you’re seeing, well, everything, and it’s terrifying, but brilliant. Then one day, like all things, it ends. You leave him, you go home, and everything’s small again. But you get used to it. And the last thing you ever, ever expect, is for him to come back.
